channel.title: Posts on R Help Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on R Help Blog

item.title: Dynamic Path to R&E Directory
item.description: header { width: 100%; text-align: left; background-color: #CCCCCC; font-family:roboto; } body{ width: 50%; background-color: #FFFFFF; font-family:roboto; } h1 { color: black; text-align: left; font-family:roboto; } p { font-family:roboto; font-size: 20px; } table.minimalistBlack { font-family:roboto; width: 100%; text-align: left; border-collapse: collapse; } table.minimalistBlack td, table.minimalistBlack th { border: 1px solid #999999; padding: 5px 4px; } table.minimalistBlack tbody td { font-size: 13px; } table.minimalistBlack thead { background: #CCCCCC; background: -moz-linear-gradient(top, #d9d9d9 0%, #d1d1d1 66%, #CCCCCC 100%); background: -webkit-linear-gradient(top, #d9d9d9 0%, #d1d1d1 66%, #CCCCCC 100%); background: linear-gradient(to bottom, #d9d9d9 0%, #d1d1d1 66%, #CCCCCC 100%); border-bottom: 2px solid #000000; } table.

item.title: WT(sprint)F?
item.description: This is my attempt to help those that are relatively new to R with an often used always annoying function that no one ever really covers in R training courses. As the title may have subtly suggested, I am talking about sprintf(). Simply put, sprintf() returns character objects containing a formatted combination of input values. I will not go into all of the various formats that are available, however I will cover a few practical examples that are often used in our work here.
